steps.name: transcribe
steps.data: You. Here's the thing I'm afraid to work out. I've been afraid to work out for quite a while now. I think it derives from the same root fear that I have about medicine in general and this feeling of mortality. But less about mortality, it's more about fragility.

data.text: But for those of you who might be on the fence when it comes to the idea of working to learn something new, I offer this word of encouragement: Life is much like going to the gym. The most painful part is deciding to go. Once you get past that, it’s easy. There have been many days I have dreaded going to the gym, but once I am there and in motion, it is a pleasure. After the workout is over, I am always glad I talked myself into going.
data.title: Rich Dad Poor Dad: What The Rich Teach Their Kids About Money - That The Poor And Middle Class Do Not!
data.author: Robert T. Kiyosaki

data.text: It had been more comforting to imagine that I might eventually “optimize” myself into the kind of person who could confront such decisions without fear, feeling totally in charge of the process. I didn’t want to accept that this was never going to happen—that fear was part of the deal, and that experiencing it wouldn’t destroy me.
data.title: Four Thousand Weeks: Time Management for Mortals
data.author: Oliver Burkeman

data.text: Life becomes a “me against it” situation. When you have fear, insecurity, or weakness inside of you, and you attempt to keep it from being stimulated, there will inevitably be events and changes in life that challenge your efforts. Because you resist these changes, you feel that you are struggling with life.
data.title: The Untethered Soul: The Journey Beyond Yourself
data.author: Michael A. Singer

data.reasoning: The quote from 'Four Thousand Weeks: Time Management for Mortals' by Oliver Burkeman directly addresses the fear and discomfort associated with working towards self-improvement, which aligns with the speaker's fear of working out and vulnerability. This quote can stimulate a conversation about facing fears and embracing the process of growth despite the discomfort.

steps.name: bold
steps.data: "It had been more comforting to imagine that I might eventually **“optimize” myself** into the kind of person who could confront such decisions without fear, feeling totally in charge of the process. I didn’t want to accept that this was never going to happen—**that fear was part of the deal**, and **that experiencing it wouldn’t destroy me**.

steps.name: transcribe
steps.data: I don't know when it started. I've been working on my blog for years now, and in a way that feels like it's kind of like my legacy with all the effort that I put into it. But the truth is, I think I'm just afraid of working out. I'm afraid of pain. I have a very low pain tolerance.

data.text: A problem arose, though, with my decision to become a professional writer: the question of how to keep physically fit.
data.title: What I Talk About When I Talk About Running (Vintage International)
data.author: Haruki Murakami and Philip Gabriel

data.text: But for those of you who might be on the fence when it comes to the idea of working to learn something new, I offer this word of encouragement: Life is much like going to the gym. The most painful part is deciding to go. Once you get past that, it’s easy. There have been many days I have dreaded going to the gym, but once I am there and in motion, it is a pleasure. After the workout is over, I am always glad I talked myself into going.
data.title: Rich Dad Poor Dad: What The Rich Teach Their Kids About Money - That The Poor And Middle Class Do Not!
data.author: Robert T. Kiyosaki

data.text: will not delude my readers with the idea, as many do, that anyone can be an abnormally strong man, nor with the statement that I commenced as an invalid and gradually worked up to my present strength. No! I have always been strong, and I can only guess what it feels like to be weak. My strength is still growing and I glory in it.
data.title: The Development of Physical Power
data.author: Arthur Saxon

data.reasoning: The second quote about the comparison between life and going to the gym can stimulate a conversation about overcoming fears and the mental blocks associated with starting new endeavors, which directly relates to the fear of working out mentioned in the transcription.

steps.name: bold
steps.data: But for those of you who might be on the fence when it comes to the idea of working to learn something new, **I offer this word of encouragement:** Life is much like going to the gym. **The most painful part is deciding to go.** Once you get past that, it’s easy. There have been many days I have dreaded going to the gym, but once I am there and in motion, **it is a pleasure.** After the workout is over, **I am always glad I talked myself into going.**
